job_title: RN Circulator in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: The teamwork amongst the nurses and scrub techs is top notch here. For the most part, you have the equipment and materials needed to really feel like you're doing your best for the patient. Very patient focused and patient outcomes are excellent.
cons: Unfortunately, the higher-ups are unwilling to recognize that due to benefit cut backs and pay that does not compete with other local hospitals, OHH is no longer the "Disneyland" that everyone used to believe it to be. Here nurses are truly just another number in the eyes of administration. "If you don't like it, leave". seems to be the attitude. Hold meetings to discuss why staff is leaving but will not do anything to fix the problem. When you take call here, count on working. Call crew consistently works 12+ hours. This may not seem like much, but when you have to stay late and work extra every-single-time you're on call it gets old quickly.

review_title: Excellent hospital and place to work

job_title: PCCU RN Staff in Edmond, OK
pros: -Great management and leadership, awesome benefits, amazing colleagues, and great patient ratio. I also loved the small hospital size and the culture and values of OHH.
cons: I am not able to think of any cons.

job_title: Security Officer in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: The pay and benefits were absolutely outstanding. Majority of the administrators and staff were genuinely nice people.
cons:
The leadership I personally experienced in Security. I'm an ex police officer and the way the security supervisor treated his officers was completely out of line. Security was highly trained and fully equipped but they were not allowed to ever touch anything on their belt or they would be fired. We were told we weren't even allowed to defend ourselves or anyone else if things went wrong.

They had an unhealthy obsession with their image. At the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, a nurse was fired for wearing a mask because the admin didn't want the patients to think they were at risk for COVID.

I was fired on the spot by my supervisor when he learned I had applied for a reservist position at a police department. I was told by him that working as a police officer would "infect" my job at the hospital. Even though he was the chief of police in a small down in Oklahoma at the time. After I left, the old supervisor stalked and threatened me on one occasion.

Fortunately, the problems were resolved when I spoke to OK Heart hospital's human resources and they told the supervisor to leave me alone.

review_title: Great Place: Adaptable and Treats You Well
job_title: Support Specialist in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: The company itself has a very fun, friendly, and personal feel.  You meet people and greet by first name.  You work closely and get a sense of ownership about the company.  The company has adapted through many changes with legislation which has been difficult to do, but they've done it.  And they treat their employees well with pay, great benefits, and awesome compensation packages.
cons: Being in technology, there for a time was a failure to understand the nature of technology.  More specifically, the clinical environment runs off of immediate knowledge.  So many users expect us to know all the answers immediately.  With technology, however, it's about analysis and troubleshooting.  So it requires a process, not an immediate recall.  It's also kind of hard to work up.  I managed a promotion, but because many people liked me and I fit the job.  Things like the above are changing, though, in my experience

job_title: Registered Nurse in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Coworkers are the best. Most are very willing to help and work as a team. The pay is good. Self scheduling is nice.
cons: The place is VERY cliquish! How you are treated by house resource and management depends on being part of the in group.  Overall atmosphere and morale has been on a huge downward turn. No longer a fun or rewarding place to work. Treating patients as royalty has turned many repeat customers into demanding spoiled brats. Physicians can be very mean and abusive.  No one has the nurses back any more. Being competent just gets you a heavier workload. Incompetency is rewarded with an easy workload. The turn over rate is really increasing. Everyone I know is looking for another job. And the new hires are not the caliber they used to be.  Recent changes in upper management have not been good. I feel like the place is in crisis.

review_title: Business Office Does Not Promote "Enter With a Happy Heart"
job_title: in Oklahoma City, OK

cons: Human Resource does not represent the employees, Business office management thrives in gossip and negativity. They speak to the public and higher ups how they treat the employees equally  but it is far from true.  The environment comes off as if you are not "buddy buddy or friends" with certain people then you are a peon within the business office

review_title: Avoid if you work in IT
job_title: IT Specialist in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: The benefits are decent, and the food really is as good as they say.
cons:
Here we go... 

Do not work here if you are in IT. The IT department here is a complete mess of leadership failures. 

People fear for their jobs. Morale is low.

The leadership here is real bad. There is micromanagement galore. Their solution to most problems is hire another mid level manager. 

Anyone who has worked with doctors knows how difficult they can be. This hospital is physician owned, so they have final say. A doctor dropped their personal phone and cracked the screen? Well, IT better drop what they're doing and get a loaner and replacement asap. This is now highest priority.

IT has even had to drop fixing hospital equipment to make an emergency run to help setup a sound system for a party leadership was throwing at a local event center.

The hospital culture is toxic. I could write a book about it. 

Merit is based on who you know and who you're related to. There are incompetent people that are un-fireable due to being related to someone higher up, or just being too good of a yes-man. And then there are hard working people that never get promoted, or get fired because of budgetary reasons. 

Every quarter leadership puts on 10 quarterly presentations cast to the other locations. It's all hands on deck in IT to try and get our mess of a over engineered proprietary telepresence system operational. If the system messes up during a presentation, there's a good chance someone in IT is getting fired. It's happened before.

The leadership person in charge of these presentations is the worst person I've ever had the displeasure of working with. She will throw tantrums, sling insults, and request people be fired on a whim. She hates IT, and goes out of her way to make our jobs difficult. I won't say who she is though. Just saying.

Lastly, I don't know who wrote that "kick the tires and light the fires" review here, but I can promise you they don't work in IT. It sounds like a review leadership would write in response to our high turnover rate. And yes that is something leadership here would do.
